meta.dataset: Drivest Life in the UK – Expanded Theory Pack (Original Structured Content)
meta.note: This is an original structured learning pack based on core Life in the UK themes. It is not a verbatim copy of the official handbook.

chapters.title: The Values and Principles of the UK
chapters.overview: This chapter explains the core principles that underpin British society including democracy, rule of law, individual liberty, and mutual respect and tolerance.

sections.title: Democracy and Participation
sections.summary: The UK is a parliamentary democracy where citizens elect representatives to make decisions on their behalf.
key_points: Voting in elections is a fundamental right of eligible citizens.
The UK uses secret ballots to protect voter privacy.
General elections typically occur every five years.
quick_checks: How often are general elections held?

sections.title: Rule of Law
sections.summary: Everyone in the UK is subject to the law, including government officials and the monarchy.
key_points: Laws are created by Parliament.
Independent courts ensure fair trials.
Police enforce laws but must follow legal procedures.
quick_checks: Who makes laws in the UK?

sections.title: Mutual Respect and Tolerance
sections.summary: British society values freedom of belief and expression within the limits of the law.
key_points: People are free to follow any religion or none.
Discrimination based on race, religion, gender, or sexuality is unlawful.
Respect for diversity is a key societal principle.
quick_checks: What law protects people from discrimination?
Can people choose not to follow a religion in the UK?

chapters.title: A Brief History of Britain
chapters.overview: This chapter summarises major historical periods that shaped modern Britain, from early settlements to the modern constitutional monarchy.

sections.title: Early Britain and Roman Rule
sections.summary: Early settlers, Roman invasion, and the development of towns and infrastructure laid foundations for Britain.
key_points: Romans invaded Britain in AD 43.
Hadrian’s Wall marked the northern boundary of Roman Britain.
Roman roads and towns influenced later development.
quick_checks: When did the Romans invade Britain?
What was Hadrian’s Wall built for?

sections.title: The Middle Ages and Magna Carta
sections.summary: The Norman Conquest and later developments shaped governance and law.
key_points: 1066: Norman Conquest led by William the Conqueror.
Magna Carta (1215) limited the powers of the King.
Parliament gradually developed as a governing institution.

sections.title: Industrial Revolution to Modern Britain
sections.summary: Industrialisation transformed Britain into a global power.
key_points: Industrial Revolution began in the 18th century.
Britain played a major role in both World Wars.
Post-war Britain developed the welfare state and NHS.
quick_checks: Why was the Industrial Revolution significant?

chapters.title: The UK Government and Political System
chapters.overview: Explains how the UK is governed, including Parliament, the Prime Minister, local government, and devolved administrations.

sections.title: Parliament Structure
sections.summary: Parliament consists of the House of Commons and House of Lords.
key_points: House of Commons members are elected.
House of Lords members are appointed or hereditary.
The Monarch formally approves legislation.
common_exam_focus: Role of the Monarch in law-making.

sections.title: Prime Minister and Cabinet
sections.summary: The Prime Minister is the head of government and selects Cabinet ministers.
key_points: PM is leader of the majority party in Commons.
Cabinet makes key policy decisions.
Collective responsibility applies to Cabinet decisions.
quick_checks: How is the Prime Minister chosen?

sections.title: Local Government and Devolution
sections.summary: Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland have devolved administrations.
key_points: Scottish Parliament, Senedd (Wales), and Northern Ireland Assembly exist.
Local councils manage services like education and waste collection.
Some powers remain reserved to UK Parliament.
quick_checks: What services do local councils provide?

chapters.title: Modern UK Society
chapters.overview: Covers everyday life including education, healthcare, employment, and civic responsibilities.

sections.title: Healthcare and NHS
sections.summary: The NHS provides healthcare funded by taxation.
key_points: NHS founded in 1948.
Most services are free at point of use.
Emergency services are accessible nationwide.

sections.title: Education System
sections.summary: Education is compulsory for children between certain ages.
key_points: Children must attend school between 5 and 18 (with training options after 16).
State schools are funded by government.
Ofsted inspects schools in England.
quick_checks: Until what age is education compulsory?

sections.title: Rights and Responsibilities
sections.summary: Residents have legal rights but also civic duties.
key_points: Pay taxes and National Insurance.
Serve on jury if summoned.
Respect laws and community standards.

chapters.title: Culture and Traditions
chapters.overview: Describes national symbols, holidays, sports, and cultural contributions.

sections.title: National Symbols
sections.summary: The UK has symbols representing its nations.
key_points: Union Flag combines England, Scotland, and Ireland crosses.
National flowers: Rose (England), Thistle (Scotland), Daffodil (Wales), Shamrock (Northern Ireland).

sections.title: Public Holidays and Celebrations
sections.summary: The UK observes bank holidays and national commemorations.
key_points: Christmas Day and Easter are major Christian festivals.
Remembrance Day is observed on 11 November.
Guy Fawkes Night is celebrated on 5 November.

sections.title: Sports and Arts
sections.summary: Sport and arts are integral to UK identity.
key_points: Football, rugby, and cricket are popular sports.
Wimbledon is a major tennis tournament.
The UK has strong literary and theatrical traditions.
quick_checks: Name one major UK sporting event.
